ER Spin Rate.description: ER Spin Rate only affects audio when ER Spin is enabled

ER Spin Amount.description: ER Spin Amount only affects audio when ER Spin is enabled

In Filter Width.description: Filter width only affects audio when at least one cut filter is enabled

In Filter Freq.description: Filter frequency only affects audio when at least one cut filter is enabled

audio_knowledge.audio_principle: Mimics natural acoustics where first reflections arrive after the initial sound travels to surfaces
audio_knowledge.audio_function: Time delay before reverb starts after the direct sound

sonic_effect.decreasing: Reverb blends immediately with sound; tighter, more integrated
sonic_effect.increasing: Creates separation between dry signal and reverb; sounds clearer and more spacious

relationships: Longer predelay + long decay = very spacious, ambient
Affects perception of room size - longer predelay suggests larger space

typical_values.full_range: Both filters off or wide open

audio_knowledge.audio_principle: Filters the signal before it enters the reverb, shaping what gets reverberated

sonic_effect.lowpass: Removes highs from reverb; darker, warmer, more distant
sonic_effect.highpass: Removes lows from reverb; cleaner, tighter low end

relationships: Different from output filtering - this affects what goes IN
Use with In Filter Width to control filter slope

audio_knowledge.audio_function: Speed of early reflection pattern rotation

sonic_effect.increasing: Faster spinning; more motion in stereo field

Works with ER Spin Amount to control depth

sonic_effect.increasing: Wider stereo movement; more dramatic panning

Lower amount with faster rate = shimmer

audio_knowledge.audio_function: Morphs early reflection pattern character
relationships: Affects how room character is perceived
Interacts with overall diffusion setting

audio_knowledge.audio_principle: In nature, high frequencies absorb faster than lows in most spaces
audio_knowledge.audio_function: High frequency cutoff/shelf for reverb output

sonic_effect.decreasing: Darker, warmer reverb; more vintage or distant
sonic_effect.increasing: Brighter, airier reverb; more present and modern

relationships: Use with HiFilter Type (shelving vs low-pass)
Shelving is gentler, low-pass is more aggressive

audio_knowledge.audio_principle: Controls low frequency content to manage clarity vs warmth
audio_knowledge.audio_function: Low frequency shelf point for reverb output

sonic_effect.cut: Cleaner, tighter reverb; less mud in low end
sonic_effect.boost: Fuller, warmer reverb with more body and weight

Often cut lows for clarity, boost for warmth

audio_knowledge.audio_principle: Adds movement and richness through pitch variation
audio_knowledge.audio_function: Speed of pitch modulation in reverb tail

Requires Chorus On to be active

audio_knowledge.audio_principle: Controls how far the pitch varies from original
audio_knowledge.audio_function: Depth of pitch modulation in reverb tail

Lower amount with faster rate = subtle movement

audio_knowledge.audio_principle: Simulates how quickly sound energy dissipates in a space based on absorption
audio_knowledge.audio_function: Duration of the reverb tail - how long it takes to fade out

sonic_effect.decreasing: Shorter, controlled tail; tighter, punchier, cleaner
sonic_effect.increasing: Longer, more sustained tail; ethereal, washy, atmospheric

relationships: Must balance with Dry/Wet - long decay needs less wet to avoid mud
Should scale with Room Size for realism
Interacts with tempo - too long causes rhythmic smearing

audio_knowledge.audio_principle: Simulates how many surfaces scatter sound and how evenly they do it
audio_knowledge.audio_function: Controls the density and smoothness of reverb reflections

sonic_effect.decreasing: Sparse, grainy texture; individual echoes more audible
sonic_effect.increasing: Dense, smooth, creamy reverb texture; individual echoes blend together

relationships: Higher diffusion softens early reflections
Works with Diffuse/Reflect levels to shape overall texture

audio_knowledge.audio_principle: Adjusts the time spacing between early reflections without changing room size parameter
audio_knowledge.audio_function: Scales the perceived size of early reflections

sonic_effect.decreasing: Early reflections suggest smaller space; more intimate
sonic_effect.increasing: Early reflections suggest larger space; more spacious feel

Affects early reflection pattern without changing decay

relationships: New audio doesn't enter while frozen
Creates pad-like textures from transients

typical_values.smooth_reverb: On for less pronounced room character

Creates smoother transition from early to late reverb

Useful for non-realistic ambient effects

sonic_effect.increasing: Larger space; longer initial reflections; more diffuse, distant sound

sonic_effect.increasing: Emphasizes space character; more defined, present reflections

High reflect level makes room size more apparent

sonic_effect.increasing: Emphasizes smooth, sustained tail; more lush and ambient

High diffuse level with long decay creates ambient wash

description.what: A stereo delay effect featuring a prominent mid-range bandpass filter applied to its repeats. It creates a distinctly asymmetrical stereo echo, with a rhythmic, lo-fi repeat primarily on the left channel (approximately three 16th notes delayed), while the right channel's delay is minimal or almost immediate. The filtered repeats have a distinct 'telephonic' or 'old radio' character due to the filter being centered around 1.7 kHz.
description.why: The bandpass filter (centered at 1.7 kHz with moderate width) is the core element, shaping the repeats to sound distinct, lo-fi, or 'telephonic' by cutting out low rumble and harsh highs. The highly asymmetrical delay times (left ~3/16th note, right near zero) create an unbalanced stereo effect, making the rhythmic, filtered repeat predominantly audible on the left, which is further enforced by both channels being tempo-synced. Moderate feedback (58.17%) ensures multiple, noticeable repeats, while the 33% dry/wet mix allows the effect to blend well without overwhelming the dry signal.
when: Adding a unique, rhythmic, and filtered echo to lead vocals or ad-libs, making them cut through the mix with a vintage character.
Processing guitars (especially arpeggios or lead lines) to create a rhythmic, lo-fi texture that adds width without sounding cluttered.
Applying to synth leads or pads to introduce a filtered, rhythmic counterpoint that sounds distinct and spatially biased to the left.
Using for sound design or special effects to create a 'through-a-wall' or 'radio transmission' quality with synchronized echoes.
When an unbalanced, ear-catching stereo echo is desired for rhythmic interest and spatial manipulation, emphasizing one side.

audio_engineering.feedback_character: Band-passed repeats that decay around 1.7 kHz due to an active filter in the feedback loop. The moderate-to-high feedback (58.17%) allows these filtered echoes to sustain and be prominent, creating a textured, resonant decay focused on the mid-range.
audio_engineering.filtering: An active bandpass filter centered at approximately 1725 Hz with a width of 2.82 is applied to the delayed signal, significantly shaping the frequency content of the repeats by allowing only the specified mid-range frequencies to pass through and decay.
audio_engineering.modulation: Modulation is technically enabled with a frequency of 2.1 Hz, but it is not routed to affect the delay time or the filter frequency (amounts are 0), resulting in no audible modulation on these parameters.
audio_engineering.stereo_behavior: Features an asymmetrical stereo delay. The left channel has a distinct rhythmic delay (2.83 16th notes), while the right channel's extremely short or negative delay time (-0.17 16ths) creates a subtle phase or comb-filtering effect rather than a clear echo. There is no ping-pong effect.
audio_engineering.timing_character: Tempo-synced, with a rhythmic delay of approximately 2.83 16th notes on the left channel. The right channel's very short, almost instantaneous delay (-0.17 16ths) creates a distinct asymmetrical timing, where rhythmic repeats are primarily heard from the left.
audio_engineering.sync_mode: Both left and right delay times are tempo-synced to the project's BPM.
use_cases: Creating distinctive, mid-range focused rhythmic echoes for synths, guitars, or specific vocal elements.
Adding textural space to sounds with a band-passed, asymmetrical delay.
Experimental rhythmic effects where one stereo side is significantly more delayed than the other, emphasizing a specific frequency range.

warnings.frequency_buildup: Specific frequency resonance: While a filter is active, the combination of 58.17% feedback and a bandpass filter with a width of 2.82 centered at 1.7 kHz could lead to a strong, potentially resonant buildup of frequencies around 1.7 kHz. This specific mid-range frequency might become overbearing or even self-oscillate if the filter's Q is high and feedback is not carefully monitored.
warnings.cpu_usage: Moderate: Standard delay processing with filtering and modulation (though modulation isn't routed to delay or filter in this preset) should not be excessively CPU-intensive. No complex algorithms like diffusion or granular processing are indicated.
warnings.low_end_accumulation: Low risk: The active bandpass filter (Filter Freq 1724.97 Hz, Filter Width 2.82) will effectively high-pass the delayed signal, preventing low frequencies from being fed back and accumulating. This helps maintain a clean low end in the mix.
warnings.mono_compatibility: Good: L/R offsets are zero, and delay times are linked, minimizing phase issues. Ping Pong is off, which generally aids mono compatibility by preventing cross-channel signal routing that could cause phase cancellation when summed.
warnings.mix_context: High impact: With 58.17% feedback and a bandpass filter centered at 1.7 kHz with a width of 2.82, the repeats will be very prominent and tonally distinct. The non-standard '2.83 16th' delay time, even if synced, may create an unusual rhythmic feel that needs careful placement to avoid clashing with other elements, especially in the busy mid-range where the filter is focused.

tighter.explanation: Reduces the number of repeats and tightens the sound by narrowing the bandpass filter and decreasing modulation, making the echoes less diffuse and present.

closer.explanation: Reduces the overall prominence of the delay effect by decreasing the wet signal level and shortening the repeats, making them feel closer to the source and ensuring no stereo offsets.

wider.explanation: Activates Ping Pong mode and introduces differential L/R offsets to create a significantly wider stereo image for the delay repeats.

narrower.explanation: Ensures Ping Pong mode is off and L/R offsets are zero, reducing the stereo width of the delay repeats to mono or near-mono.

warmer.explanation: Shifts the bandpass filter frequency lower to emphasize warmer, bassier frequencies in the delay repeats, slightly widening the band to include more low-mids.

further.explanation: Increases the wet signal and feedback for a more spacious, ambient sound, while introducing slight stereo offsets to make the repeats feel further away through a Haas effect.

looser.explanation: Increases the feedback for longer, more ambient repeats, widens the bandpass filter, and adds more modulation for a less precise, more diffused sound.

brighter.explanation: Shifts the bandpass filter frequency higher to emphasize brighter, more prominent frequencies in the delay repeats, with a slightly narrower band for focus.

description.what: A subtle, short, free-running delay with a stereo ping-pong effect and tone-shaped repeats.
description.why: This preset combines a short, unsynced delay time (120ms) with low feedback (21%) and a subtle dry/wet mix (20%) to create a non-intrusive echo. The 'Ping Pong' mode actively bounces the repeats between the left and right channels, significantly enhancing the stereo width. An active filter at 1200 Hz shapes the tone of the repeats, ensuring they blend smoothly and don't muddy the mix, making the sound feel more present and expansive without being overtly delayed.
when: To add presence and thickness to lead vocals without overt echoing.
For fattening up rhythm guitars or creating a classic rockabilly/country slapback feel.
To provide subtle stereo width and movement to static synthesizer sounds or pads.
Enhancing the impact or sustain of percussive elements like snare drums or claps.
Adding a discreet sense of space and dimension to any dry instrument in a mix.

audio_engineering.feedback_character: Moderate feedback at 21%, repeats are shaped by a filter centered at 1200 Hz. Freeze is inactive.
audio_engineering.filtering: Active filter centered at 1200 Hz with a width setting of 9.00 (likely Q or resonance), shaping the frequency content of the delay repeats.
audio_engineering.modulation: Modulation source is active at 0.55 Hz, but it is currently not modulating the delay time or the filter frequency.
audio_engineering.stereo_behavior: Ping-pong effect is active, creating a stereo bouncing effect between the left and right channels. The Left and Right delay times are linked.
audio_engineering.timing_character: Unsynced delay time of 120.34 milliseconds, which falls into the slapback or very short echo range.
audio_engineering.sync_mode: Millisecond (ms) mode; the delay time is not synced to the host tempo.
use_cases: Slapback delay (due to 120ms time and moderate feedback)
Short stereo echoes with a bouncing (ping-pong) effect

warnings.frequency_buildup: With a very low 'Feedback' percentage of 21% and an active filter set at 1200Hz within the feedback loop, there is minimal risk of uncontrolled frequency buildup or runaway echoes. The filter helps to shape the tonal quality of the few repeats rather than primarily preventing buildup.
warnings.low_end_accumulation: Given the very low 'Feedback' of 21% and an active filter at 1200Hz, significant low-end accumulation is highly improbable. The filter, regardless of its type (HPF/LPF/Bandpass), combined with the limited number of repeats, prevents any problematic build-up of low frequencies.
warnings.mono_compatibility: The 'Ping Pong' setting actively creates a stereo bouncing effect. While 'L Offset' is 0, the inherent nature of Ping Pong delays means that the left and right channels contain different information, which can lead to phase issues or signal cancellation when the mix is summed to mono. Always verify mono compatibility to ensure the delayed signal retains its clarity and presence.
warnings.mix_context: This preset, with its 20% 'Dry/Wet' mix and 'Ping Pong' enabled, creates a subtle stereo widening and slapback-like effect (120ms). Consider how this subtle stereo spread interacts with other elements in your mix, particularly those also vying for space in the stereo field. The filter at 1200Hz will shape the timbre of the repeats, so ensure this frequency contour complements the source material and the overall mix's spectral balance.

tighter.explanation: Reduces the number of repeats, the overall presence of the delay, and slightly shortens the delay time for a more controlled and less lingering effect.

closer.explanation: Reduces the amount and length of the delay, removes stereo separation and ping-pong effect, making the sound feel more immediate and spatially closer to the listener.

wider.explanation: Introduces an offset between the left and right delay lines to create a Haas effect, enhancing the stereo width and spatial dimension of the repeats.

narrower.explanation: Eliminates time differences between the left and right delay lines and turns off the ping-pong effect, collapsing the stereo image of the repeats towards mono.

warmer.explanation: Lowers the filter's frequency, rolling off some high frequencies in the repeats and allowing them to linger slightly longer, for a mellower and warmer sound.

further.explanation: Increases the amount and length of the delay, adds more feedback, and introduces stereo offset to create a more expansive, distant, and immersive spatial effect.

looser.explanation: Increases the number of repeats and the overall prominence of the delay, creating a longer, more ambient and spacious echo.

brighter.explanation: Raises the filter's frequency range, allowing more high frequencies to pass through the repeats, resulting in a more crisp and present delay.

description.what: An extremely long, wide, and smooth ambient reverb, designed to transform sounds into vast, evolving textures and sustained soundscapes. With a decay time of 10 minutes, it creates an almost infinite wash that is fully wet and rich in detail.
description.why: To generate an incredibly long, wide, and smooth ambient wash that fundamentally transforms sounds into sustained, evolving textures, rather than merely placing them in a conventional space. It emphasizes a 'less natural, more textural' approach to reverb, with high input clarity and a bright, but filtered, tail.
when: Creating expansive, ethereal soundscapes or drones.
Adding an 'infinity reverb' effect to pads or sustained instruments.
Transforming short percussive hits or samples into lingering atmospheric elements.
For experimental sound design where extreme, evolving tails are desired.
On a dedicated send/return track to blend a huge wash with dry signals.

audio_engineering.frequency_character: Clear and bright in the tail (due to high shelf), with an input high-cut to prevent initial harshness. Flat low-end.

use_cases.context: Adding subtle depth, width, and a sense of a small ambient space to a snare drum without a long, distracting tail. Enhances punch and presence.
use_cases.eq_rationale: Prevents low-end rumble from muddying the reverb and high-end harshness from building up in the short, bright tail.
use_cases.eq_prep: High-pass the snare signal pre-reverb at 200-300 Hz. Apply a gentle low-pass at 8-10 kHz to tame sizzle.
use_cases.send_level_rationale: Enough to give the snare dimension and width, but kept short to maintain rhythmic clarity and avoid excessive wash.
use_cases.notes: The 15ms pre-delay helps keep the snare's initial transient clear. The wide stereo image makes the snare feel bigger.

use_cases.context: Placing a lead vocal in an intimate, ambient space that adds presence and subtle air without smearing intelligibility. Ideal for a 'close-mic, small room' feel.
use_cases.eq_rationale: Removes unnecessary low-end rumble and tames harsh high frequencies before they interact with the reverb, keeping the vocal clean.
use_cases.eq_prep: High-pass the vocal signal pre-reverb at 150-200 Hz. Consider a gentle low-pass at 6-7 kHz if the vocal is prone to sibilance, or use a de-esser.
use_cases.send_level_rationale: The reverb should act as a subtle halo around the vocal, maintaining its upfront position and clarity in the mix.
use_cases.notes: The 15ms pre-delay is crucial for maintaining vocal clarity. The wide stereo image can make the vocal sound more enveloping without sounding washed out.

use_cases.context: Providing a shimmering, subtle ambience to clean or arpeggiated guitar parts, enhancing their stereo presence and adding a pleasant sense of space.
use_cases.eq_rationale: Removes any low-end mud or rumble from the guitar that could accumulate in the reverb, ensuring a clean and focused ambience.
use_cases.eq_prep: High-pass the guitar signal pre-reverb at 120-150 Hz.
use_cases.send_level_rationale: Sufficient to give the guitar a noticeable, airy ambience without overpowering its dry signal or making it sound too distant.
use_cases.notes: The short decay combined with the wide stereo image creates a pleasant, non-intrusive spaciousness that suits clean and delicate guitar textures.

use_cases.context: Applying a subtle, cohesive 'room' effect to a drum bus to glue the individual elements together in a small, tight space, enhancing overall stereo image.
use_cases.eq_rationale: Prevents the low-end energy from kick drums and bass elements from creating muddiness or unwanted boominess in the reverb tail.
use_cases.eq_prep: High-pass the drum bus signal pre-reverb at 100-120 Hz.
use_cases.send_level_rationale: Just enough to create a sense of shared space and cohesion among the drum elements, rather than a distinct, large room effect.
use_cases.notes: The short decay ensures that the drum groove remains tight and punchy, while the wide stereo image expands the drum soundstage subtly.

warnings.frequency_buildup: Both the `In LowCut On` and `LowShelf On` parameters are disabled, meaning no low-frequency filtering is applied to the input signal or the reverb tail. This creates a high risk of low-frequency buildup and muddiness, especially with the extremely long `Decay Time`. Additionally, the `HiShelf Gain` of 0.733, combined with `HiFilter Freq` at 7058 Hz, suggests minimal high-frequency damping, potentially leading to a very bright, sibilant, or harsh reverb tail that persists for a very long time.
warnings.cpu_usage: The `Density` setting is at its highest (3.0), which contributes to a richer sound but also significantly increases CPU load, especially with the extremely long decay time.
warnings.low_end_accumulation: With an extremely long `Decay Time` (600 seconds) and both `In LowCut On` and `LowShelf On` disabled, this preset is highly prone to massive low-end accumulation. Any low-frequency content in the source material will sustain indefinitely, resulting in an overwhelmingly muddy and boomy sound that will quickly consume all headroom and make the mix indistinct.
warnings.mono_compatibility: The `Stereo Image` is set to 100, indicating maximum stereo width. This can lead to phase cancellation and a significant loss of impact or character when the mix is collapsed to mono. Test thoroughly in mono.
warnings.mix_context: The `Decay Time` is set to an exceptionally long 600 seconds (10 minutes). While `Dry/Wet` is 100% (suggesting a send setup), this extreme decay time will completely dominate the mix, obscuring dry signals and creating an overwhelming wash. This is highly unsuitable for most musical contexts and implies an almost infinite sustain effect, which may not be the intended 'ambience' given that `Freeze On` is off.

tighter.explanation: Reduces the reverb tail and room size, increases pre-delay for clarity, and adds low-frequency cuts to make the reverb more focused and less boomy.

closer.explanation: Decreases the pre-delay and overall diffuse tail level while slightly increasing early reflections, making the sound source feel more forward and present.

wider.explanation: Maximizes the stereo spread of the reverb and adds subtle modulation to both early reflections and the tail for a broader, more expansive sound.

narrower.explanation: Reduces the stereo width of the reverb and disables any modulation, resulting in a more focused and mono-compatible spatial effect.

warmer.explanation: Lowers the high-cut frequency on the input and reverb tail, and increases high-frequency damping, reducing harshness and making the reverb darker and smoother.

further.explanation: Increases the pre-delay and diffuse tail level while reducing early reflections, pushing the sound source further back into a larger, more ambient space.

looser.explanation: Extends the reverb tail, creates a larger and more diffuse space, and allows more low-frequency content to contribute to the wash.

brighter.explanation: Raises the high-cut frequency on the input and reverb tail, and reduces high-frequency damping, adding more sparkle and air to the reverb.

description.what: A short, smooth, and wide ambient reverb, designed to add a defined sense of space without long tails or excessive wash. It features a medium pre-delay, a small virtual room size, and high diffusion for a dense, static character, with the input slightly filtered to prevent harshness.
description.why: This preset combines a short decay (0.6s) and small room size (20) with a medium pre-delay (15ms) to create a contained yet distinct space. High diffusion and maximum density ensure a smooth, high-quality tail. The 100% stereo image provides width, while the absence of modulation (Chorus, ER Spin) and an input high-cut (6.1kHz) contribute to a static, clear, and non-harsh ambient effect, best suited for a send/return track due to its 100% wet setting.
when: Vocals (for subtle, clear space without long tails)
Snare/Percussion (to add a tight, present room feel or subtle plate-like character)
Rhythm/Clean Guitars (to provide a sense of space without blurring attack)
Synths/Pads (for subtle depth and texture, not long washes)
Acoustic Instruments (e.g., piano, acoustic guitar for naturalistic room resonance)

audio_engineering.frequency_character: Warm and controlled highs with natural lows. The input signal is high-cut at ~6.17 kHz, and the reverb tail's high-frequency decay is slightly reduced at ~7.06 kHz, resulting in a smooth, non-harsh high end. No low-frequency shaping is applied to the tail.

use_cases.context: Adds a subtle, warm, and wide space that enhances presence without washing out the lead. The moderate pre-delay maintains vocal clarity, preventing the reverb from cluttering the initial transient.
use_cases.eq_rationale: Keeps the vocal reverb clean in the low end and avoids accentuating sibilance or harsh frequencies that might become pronounced in the reverb tail.
use_cases.eq_prep: High-pass filter the vocal send around 120-150 Hz to prevent low-mid buildup in the reverb. Consider a subtle cut around 2-3 kHz if the vocal source itself is prone to harshness.
use_cases.send_level_rationale: Provides clear spatialization and warmth, allowing the reverb to be distinctly heard without overpowering the dry signal or making the vocal sound distant.
use_cases.notes: The built-in input high-cut at ~6.17 kHz effectively tames potential harshness or sibilance in the reverb itself, contributing to a smoother vocal sound.

use_cases.context: Provides a tight, punchy room sound that gives the snare body and width without a long, distracting tail. Ideal for adding impact and dimension to percussive elements.
use_cases.eq_rationale: Prevents low-frequency rumble and muddiness from the snare's low-end transients from building up in the reverb, ensuring clarity and punch.
use_cases.eq_prep: High-pass filter the snare send around 200-300 Hz. This focuses the reverb on the snare's snap and body, keeping the low end tight.
use_cases.send_level_rationale: To give the snare a noticeable, but not overwhelming, sense of space and impact that helps it sit in the mix without becoming muddy.
use_cases.notes: The 15 ms pre-delay is crucial for maintaining the snare's sharp transient, ensuring the impact is heard before the reverb begins.

use_cases.context: Creates a natural, intimate room feel that gently widens and deepens the instrument's sound without blurring individual notes. Excellent for adding subtle ambience to delicate parts.
use_cases.eq_rationale: Ensures the reverb complements the instrument's natural frequencies without adding muddiness or unwanted resonant frequencies that could detract from its clarity.
use_cases.eq_prep: High-pass filter the instrument send around 100-120 Hz to clean up potential boominess. A subtle dip around 800 Hz - 1 kHz on the send can reduce boxiness.
use_cases.send_level_rationale: To add a delicate texture and space, allowing the instrument's natural tone and articulation to remain primary, while still benefiting from spatial enhancement.
use_cases.notes: The subtle high-frequency damping helps avoid a brittle or overly bright reverb on delicate acoustic instruments, contributing to a warmer, more natural sound.

use_cases.context: Offers a smooth, wide, and slightly dark ambiance that gives pads a sense of depth and ethereal quality without extending their sustain excessively, creating a cohesive bed.
use_cases.eq_rationale: Sculpts the reverb to complement the pad's frequency content, preventing low-end build-up that could muddy the mix or harshness in the upper register.
use_cases.eq_prep: High-pass filter the send around 150-200 Hz if the pad has significant low-end content. Consider a gentle high-shelf cut if the pad is already very bright.
use_cases.send_level_rationale: To fully immerse the pad in the ambient space, enhancing its texture and creating a rich, enveloping sound without making it overly wet or indistinct.
use_cases.notes: The short decay time combined with moderate diffusion ensures the texture is added smoothly without creating an overly long, muddy wash, allowing other elements to cut through.

warnings.frequency_buildup: Both 'In LowCut On' and 'LowShelf On' are disabled, meaning no low-frequency filtering is applied to the input or the reverb tail. This can lead to an accumulation of low-end frequencies in the reverb, potentially causing muddiness.
warnings.cpu_usage: High 'Density' (3.000) uses the highest quality setting, which can be CPU intensive, especially on complex projects.
warnings.low_end_accumulation: Lack of low-cut filtering on the input ('In LowCut On: 0.000') and no low-shelf on the reverb tail ('LowShelf On: 0.000') makes the reverb susceptible to low-end buildup, which could muddy the overall mix, especially with bass-heavy sources.
warnings.mono_compatibility: High 'Stereo Image' (100%) can lead to mono compatibility issues; check mix in mono to ensure clarity and balance.
warnings.mix_context: The 'Dry/Wet' is set to 100% wet. This preset is intended for use on a send/return track. If used as an insert effect on a track, it will completely replace the dry signal, which is generally not suitable for 'Ambience Medium' and may obscure the original sound.

tighter.explanation: Shortens the reverb tail, reduces the diffuse level, and cleans up low-frequency buildup by activating input and output low cuts, resulting in a more controlled and less muddy sound.

closer.explanation: Reduces the delay before the reverb starts, brings early reflections forward, and lessens the lingering tail, making the sound source feel more upfront and intimate.

wider.explanation: Maximizes the stereo spread and introduces modulation to both early reflections and the tail via chorus and ER spin, creating a broader, more expansive stereo image.

narrower.explanation: Reduces the stereo spread of the reverb and disables modulation effects, focusing the reverb sound more towards the center for a tighter, less expansive feel.

warmer.explanation: Damps high frequencies both before and within the reverb tail by lowering filter frequencies and reducing high-shelf gain, while subtly boosting lows, resulting in a darker, richer sound.

further.explanation: Increases the gap before the reverb, reduces early reflections, and extends the diffuse tail with a larger room size, pushing the sound source further into the sonic space.

looser.explanation: Extends the reverb tail and room size, widens the stereo image, and introduces subtle modulation through chorus and ER spin, creating a more open and spacious feel.

brighter.explanation: Enhances high frequencies by deactivating input high-cut and increasing output high-shelf gain and frequency, while subtly cutting lows to emphasize sparkle and air.

description.what: A vast, dark, and highly diffused ambient reverb with an exceptionally long predelay.
description.why:
1. **Extreme Clarity & Depth:** The very long predelay (56ms) creates maximum separation between the dry signal and the reverb, ensuring the source remains upfront while a vast, dark ambience unfolds much later, providing deep spatial context without interference.
2. **Vast & Smooth Character:** A huge room size, medium-long decay, and high diffusion combine with a high-frequency cut in the tail to produce a smooth, warm, and expansive wash that is never harsh or metallic.
3. **Subtle Organic Motion:** Low amounts of early reflection spin and chorus modulation, both at very slow rates, introduce gentle, evolving movement to the tail, preventing it from sounding static and adding an organic, breathing quality to the expansive space.
when: On a send/return track, always 100% wet.
For elements that need to sit far back in the mix while retaining crisp transients.
To create a sense of immense, evolving space for pads or atmospheric sound design.
On lead vocals or orchestral elements to give them a grand, distant, yet clear presence.
When a foundational, supporting ambient bed is required without smearing the source.

audio_engineering.frequency_character: Dark (high-frequency damping) with high-passed input (clean low-mids)

use_cases.context: To provide a spacious, clean, and enveloping presence without obscuring the dry vocal.
use_cases.eq_rationale: Ensure the vocal is processed for clarity and dynamics before hitting the reverb, as the reverb will emphasize any harshness or sibilance.
use_cases.eq_prep: Standard de-essing and compression on the vocal signal.
use_cases.send_level_rationale: Allows the reverb to support the vocal without overpowering it, typical for a send effect.
use_cases.notes: The long pre-delay (57ms) is crucial for vocal clarity, separating the dry signal from the spacious tail. The high input HPF (400Hz) ensures the reverb stays clean and free of low-end mud, while darker highs prevent harshness.

use_cases.context: Creating a lush, evolving, and wide atmospheric bed for guitar textures.
use_cases.eq_rationale: Pre-EQ removes any frequencies that could become problematic or overly resonant when fed into a long, wide, and dark reverb, ensuring a smooth, ethereal texture.
use_cases.eq_prep: Roll off any harsh high-mids and apply gentle compression for sustain on the guitar signal.
use_cases.send_level_rationale: To immerse the guitar pad fully in the ambient space, allowing the reverb to become a significant part of the sound.
use_cases.notes: The combination of long pre-delay, medium decay, wide stereo, and subtle chorus (as enabled in the preset) contributes to a deep, expansive, and evolving ambient sound. The high input HPF keeps the pad from becoming muddy.

use_cases.context: Adding a distinct, deep, and slightly ethereal spatial dimension to a snare or clap, distinct from a tight room.
use_cases.eq_rationale: A clean, sharp transient is essential to clearly hear the long pre-delay and the subsequent reverb tail. Removing low-end rumble on the source prevents mud when combined with the reverb's inherent low-cut.
use_cases.eq_prep: Ensure snare/clap transients are well-defined and any unwanted low-end rumble is removed.
use_cases.send_level_rationale: To create a noticeable and impactful spatial effect on the drum hit, either as an obvious effect or a supporting layer.
use_cases.notes: The long pre-delay (57ms) creates a significant gap between the snare hit and the reverb, making the snare feel distinct and adding a unique depth. The high input HPF (400Hz) ensures the reverb doesn't add rumble to the low-end of the drum mix, keeping it clean and impactful.

use_cases.context: To give individual synth notes or arpeggiated patterns a distinct, spacious, and detached ambience without losing their attack.
use_cases.eq_rationale: Clean input ensures a clean reverb tail, preventing buildup in the lower frequencies and avoiding harshness in the upper register.
use_cases.eq_prep: Cut any unwanted low-end rumble or harsh high-frequencies from the synth itself.
use_cases.send_level_rationale: Provides a noticeable ambient layer that complements the dry synth, enhancing its presence without smearing.
use_cases.notes: The substantial pre-delay (57ms) allows the initial synth pluck to remain clear and punchy before the spacious reverb washes in. The high input HPF (400Hz) is crucial for preventing the reverb from muddying the low-end of the synth or the overall mix, especially for synths with wide frequency content. Wide stereo and subtle chorus add interest and movement.

warnings.frequency_buildup: High. The combination of an active input high-cut (low-pass filter) at 400Hz with a potentially high 'In Filter Width' (Q of 6.5) could create a resonant peak, significantly boosting frequencies around 400Hz before they even hit the reverb engine. This, coupled with the extremely large 'Room Size' and 'Decay Time' (1.68s) and the lack of a low-shelf filter in the reverb tail, creates a high risk of low-mid frequency buildup and muddiness.
warnings.cpu_usage: Moderate to High. The 'Room Size' is exceptionally large (499.776), far exceeding typical 'Hall' settings (60-80). Although 'Density' is low (0.333), which reduces CPU, the sheer scale of the simulated space could still demand significant processing power.
warnings.low_end_accumulation: High. There is no input high-pass filter ('In LowCut On: 0.000') to prevent unwanted low frequencies from exciting the reverb. Additionally, the reverb tail lacks a low-shelf filter ('LowShelf On: 0.000') to control the decay of these low frequencies. This means any bass content in the dry signal will freely enter and accumulate in the reverb, leading to a boomy or muddy mix bottom.
warnings.mono_compatibility: High. The 'Stereo Image' is set to a wide 85.7%, and both 'Chorus' and 'ER Spin' are active. While 'Chorus Amount' and 'ER Spin Rate' are low, any modulation and wide stereo processing can introduce phase issues or cause the reverb to disappear or sound thin when summed to mono.
warnings.mix_context: High. This preset generates an extremely dark and highly colored reverb. The 'In HighCut On' (input low-pass filter) is active at a very low 'In Filter Freq' of 400Hz. This means only low-mid frequencies and below will enter the reverb, creating a muffled and unnatural sound that will only suit very specific sound design applications or extremely dark ambient textures. It is unlikely to fit most mix contexts without sounding dull or detached.

tighter.explanation: To make the reverb 'tighter', we shorten the 'Decay Time' and reduce 'Room Size' for a less expansive feel. Increasing 'Predelay' helps separate the dry signal from the reverb for clarity, as per the knowledge base. We also narrow the 'Stereo Image' and reduce the 'Diffuse Level' and 'Reflect Level' to make the effect less prominent. Activating and raising the 'In Filter Freq' (low-cut) cleans up low-end mud before it excites the reverb, ensuring cleaner tails.

closer.explanation: To bring the source 'closer', we reduce the 'Predelay' for a more immediate reverb response, minimizing the separation between dry and wet. We significantly increase 'Reflect Level' to emphasize early reflections, which are proximity cues, while decreasing 'Diffuse Level' to reduce the sense of distant tail. Shortening 'Decay Time' and reducing 'Room Size' contribute to a smaller, more intimate space, making the source feel less distant.

wider.explanation: To make the reverb 'wider', we significantly increase the 'Stereo Image' for a more expansive stereo field. Boosting 'Chorus Amount' and 'Chorus Rate' adds modulation and width to the tail, as it 'adds subtle motion and width'. Similarly, increasing 'ER Spin Amount' and 'ER Spin Rate' introduces modulation to the early reflections, which can create 'wide panning artifacts' according to the knowledge base, enhancing the stereo spread.

narrower.explanation: To make the reverb 'narrower', we decrease the 'Stereo Image' to collapse the stereo field towards mono. We also reduce 'Chorus Amount' and 'Chorus Rate' to minimize the width-enhancing modulation on the tail. Decreasing 'ER Spin Amount' and 'ER Spin Rate' lessens the modulation of early reflections, reducing any potential wide panning artifacts and contributing to a more focused and centralized reverb image.

warmer.explanation: For a 'warmer' reverb, we decrease the 'HiFilter Freq' and 'HiShelf Gain' for the tail, promoting faster high-frequency decay and a darker tone. We also lower the 'In Filter Freq' of the input high-cut to reduce harsh highs before they enter the reverb, as suggested for 'de-harshing highs'. Activating the 'LowShelf' and slightly reducing its 'LowShelf Gain' helps prevent thinning of the low-end, contributing to a warmer, richer sound.

further.explanation: To place the source 'further' back, we increase 'Predelay' to create a greater gap between the direct sound and the reverb, pushing the source into the background. We boost 'Diffuse Level' to emphasize the reverb tail, which enhances the perception of distance, and decrease 'Reflect Level' to reduce proximity cues. A longer 'Decay Time' and larger 'Room Size' create a more expansive space, reinforcing the distant feel.

looser.explanation: Achieving a 'looser' reverb involves increasing the 'Decay Time' and 'Room Size' for a more expansive and sustained space. A shorter 'Predelay' blends the dry signal and reverb more closely. We widen the 'Stereo Image' and boost 'Diffuse Level' and 'Reflect Level' to enhance the overall presence. Increasing 'Diffusion' creates a smoother, denser tail, and boosting 'Chorus Amount' adds subtle motion and width, contributing to a more ambient, less defined feel.

brighter.explanation: To make the reverb 'brighter', we raise the 'HiFilter Freq' and 'HiShelf Gain' for the tail, allowing more high frequencies to sustain and sparkle. We also raise the 'In Filter Freq' of the input high-cut (or disable the input high-cut entirely via 'In HighCut On' set to 0.0) to let more high frequencies enter the reverb. Enabling the 'LowShelf' and increasing its 'LowShelf Gain' will thin out the low-end, further enhancing the perceived brightness of the reverb tail.

description.what: A very large, lush, and expansive reverb, characterized by a significant pre-delay and long decay, full stereo width, and a smooth, dense tail. The input signal's high frequencies are gently rolled off to prevent harshness in the long decay, while the reverb's low end is allowed to remain full.
description.why: To create a deeply immersive and emotionally resonant sound field, providing a sense of grandeur and sustain that enhances the expressive qualities of slower, melodic musical passages, ideal for ballads and atmospheric genres. The long pre-delay maintains source clarity, while the expansive, smooth tail provides a rich backdrop.
when: Lead Vocals (Ballads/Pop): To give a sense of emotional space and sustain to a prominent vocal without washing it out.
Pads & Synths: For creating atmospheric, evolving soundscapes with a rich, enveloping background.
Clean Guitars/Pianos: For spacious, ambient textures, allowing individual notes to sustain beautifully.
Cinematic Strings/Orchestration: To place elements in a grand, emotional concert hall-like environment.
Ambient Production: As a foundational, 100% wet texture on a send for broad sound design.

audio_engineering.predelay: 30 ms (emphasizes source clarity before reverb onset)
audio_engineering.frequency_character: Input high-cut at 3.6kHz significantly reduces high frequencies before the reverb engine, preventing harshness and sibilance from entering the reverb. The reverb tail's high-frequency shelf, active at 4.3kHz with a positive gain (0.67), means it experiences less damping and maintains a relatively bright, airy quality in the tail. There is no low-shelf filtering on the tail, so a clean, high-passed source signal is important to avoid low-end mud.

use_cases.context: Provides a grand, expansive, and emotional space for a lead vocal without washing out intelligibility. Ideal for soaring melodies.
use_cases.eq_rationale: Prevents the vocal's low frequencies from creating a muddy reverb tail and ensures harsh sibilance is removed *before* being processed by the reverb's input high-cut.
use_cases.eq_prep: Apply a gentle high-pass filter (e.g., 150-200Hz) on the vocal track before sending to the reverb to prevent low-end rumble from exciting the reverb's unfiltered low end. Use a de-esser if the vocal is sibilant before sending.
use_cases.send_level_rationale: As this is a 100% wet reverb, the send level directly controls the amount of reverb. A medium-high setting allows the vocal to sit clearly in front of the lush space, enhancing drama.
use_cases.notes: The 30ms pre-delay is crucial for maintaining vocal clarity, allowing the dry vocal to hit before the reverb bloom. The subtle early reflection spin adds organic movement.

use_cases.context: Creates a dream-like, atmospheric environment for delicate acoustic guitar passages, enhancing resonance and sustain.
use_cases.eq_rationale: Removes unwanted low-end rumble from the guitar that could accumulate in the reverb. The reverb's inherent character complements the guitar's natural brightness.
use_cases.eq_prep: High-pass the acoustic guitar at 80-100Hz. Consider a slight cut around 400-600Hz if the guitar sounds boxy in the mix before sending to reverb.
use_cases.send_level_rationale: Enough reverb to create an immersive space while preserving the intricate details and transients of the fingerpicking.
use_cases.notes: The wide stereo image and long decay make this suitable for enveloping the guitar in a beautiful, sustained sound. The high input cut helps prevent any harshness from strumming or plucking from becoming exaggerated in the reverb.

use_cases.context: Ideal for crafting vast, evolving soundscapes and providing a sense of grandeur and emotional depth to sustained synth or string textures.
use_cases.eq_rationale: Manages potential low-frequency buildup, especially with sustained sounds, ensuring the overall mix doesn't become muddy. The reverb's natural brightness works well with these sources.
use_cases.eq_prep: If the pad or string patch has significant low-end, apply a high-pass filter at 120-150Hz on the source track. No specific high-end EQ is typically needed as the reverb will provide air and sustain.
use_cases.send_level_rationale: Allows the pad/string sound to fully dissolve into the lush, wide reverb for maximum atmospheric effect and space creation.
use_cases.notes: The very long decay and wide stereo image are perfect for creating massive, sustained washes of sound. The subtle ER spin adds a dynamic quality to the evolving texture.

use_cases.context: Simulates the natural, resonant acoustic of a grand concert hall, perfect for expressive piano pieces in a ballad setting.
use_cases.eq_rationale: Ensures the piano's low end remains clean and defined, preventing the reverb from becoming boomy. The reverb's clear, bright tail complements the piano's upper harmonics.
use_cases.eq_prep: Apply a gentle high-pass filter around 80-100Hz on the piano track to remove any sub-harmonic rumble. Consider a slight cut around 200-300Hz if the piano's low-mids are too thick.
use_cases.send_level_rationale: Provides a beautiful sense of space and resonance without obscuring the piano's attack or clarity, allowing emotional dynamics to shine.
use_cases.notes: The 30ms pre-delay is vital for piano, allowing the clear attack of the notes to precede the spacious reverberation, preserving definition and impact for a natural hall sound.

audio_engineering.diffusion: Medium-High (60%, for a smooth, dense tail without excessive blurring)

warnings.frequency_buildup: The 'LowShelf On' parameter is set to OFF (0.000), meaning there's no low-frequency damping on the reverb tail. This, combined with the 'In LowCut On' parameter also being OFF (0.000), means the reverb will be processing the full low-frequency content of the input without any pre-filtering. This significantly increases the risk of low-end muddiness and frequency buildup, especially given the long 3-second decay time.
warnings.cpu_usage: The 'Density' parameter is set to its maximum (3.000), which according to the knowledge base means 'smoother/richer tails at higher CPU cost.' This preset will likely be CPU-intensive.
warnings.low_end_accumulation: Due to both the input low-cut filter ('In LowCut On') and the low shelf filter for the tail ('LowShelf On') being disabled, the reverb will accumulate significant low-frequency energy over its 3-second decay. This can lead to a boomy, muddy, or undefined low-end in the mix, as the reverb's lower frequencies are not being thinned or removed before/during processing.
warnings.mono_compatibility: The 'Stereo Image' is set to 100% (fully wide), which can lead to phase issues or a significant loss of spatial presence when the mix is collapsed to mono. Test carefully in mono.
warnings.mix_context: With a 'Decay Time' of 3 seconds and a 'Room Size' of 99.988, this reverb creates a very large, lush, and long-sustaining space. While suitable for ballads, pads, or cinematic sounds, it might overwhelm faster-paced tracks or cause muddiness if applied to every element without careful EQ and level management. The 30ms 'Predelay' is on the longer side, which can push the source further back in the mix, potentially detaching it from the dry signal.

tighter.explanation: Shortens the reverb tail, reduces room size, and tightens the low-end of the reverb for a more defined and less lingering sound.

closer.explanation: Reduces the pre-delay and emphasizes early reflections over the diffuse tail, making the sound source feel more upfront and intimate within the space.

wider.explanation: Expands the stereo spread of the reverb by increasing the stereo image, enabling chorus modulation, and enhancing early reflection spin for a broader soundstage.

narrower.explanation: Reduces the stereo spread of the reverb by decreasing the stereo image and disabling chorus and early reflection spin, pushing the reverb towards a more mono sound.

warmer.explanation: Dampens high frequencies in the reverb tail and input, while subtly boosting lower frequencies, resulting in a darker, less harsh, and richer tone.

further.explanation: Increases the pre-delay and emphasizes the diffuse tail over early reflections, making the sound source feel more distant and enveloped by the reverb.

looser.explanation: Extends the reverb tail, increases room size, and makes the reflections smoother and denser for a more expansive and sustained sound.

brighter.explanation: Enhances high frequencies in the reverb tail and input, and reduces low-end emphasis, making the reverb more airy, present, and sparkling.

description.what: A dark, dense, and muffled reverb simulating a small, enclosed concrete space. It heavily filters high frequencies from the input, creating a distinct gloomy, lo-fi character with a subtle metallic edge and wide stereo spread.
description.why: To evoke the sound of a small, hard-surfaced, heavily dampened (in the high frequencies) environment. It provides a unique, character-driven ambience that adds mood, weight, and grit without contributing perceived 'air' or 'sparkle' to the sound. The combination of small size, short pre-delay, and aggressive input filtering creates a claustrophobic yet dense effect.
when: Drums (snare, toms) for a gritty, non-bright room sound.
Industrial or experimental tracks to create an oppressive atmosphere.
Background vocals or vocal effects requiring a distant, dark, and lo-fi treatment.
Synth pads or drones to add a dense, murky, and evolving tail without brightness.
Guitars (especially distorted) to impart a heavy, subterranean, or bunker-like feel.

audio_engineering.size: Compact and dense, with high diffusion (60%) and high scale (90) to prevent metallic ringing despite the small room size (10).
audio_engineering.frequency_character: Input high-cut at 4.3 kHz to tame harshness before reverb. The reverb tail itself features a subtle low-shelf boost (+0.2 dB) at 101 Hz, adding warmth to the low-mids, and a subtle high-shelf boost (+0.2 dB) at 1.68 kHz, adding some presence without being overly bright.
audio_engineering.stereo_width: Very wide (100% stereo image) with subtle chorus modulation (Amount 4.0, Rate 0.46 Hz) to enhance movement and lushness.

use_cases.context: Adding character and depth to percussive elements without excessive wash. The short pre-delay and small size keep it relatively tight, while the 1.8s decay provides sustain. Good for a 'trashy' or 'character' drum room sound.
use_cases.eq_rationale: Prevents low-end rumble from creating mud in the reverb and controls potential harsh high-end from cymbals or snare hits.
use_cases.eq_prep: High-pass filter drums around 100-150 Hz; low-pass filter around 8-10 kHz.
use_cases.send_level_rationale: To blend the character into the dry drum sound without overpowering it, allowing the distinct texture to shine through.
use_cases.notes: The unique combination of small size and longer decay with high diffusion creates a distinct, somewhat resonant character, which can be creatively used for percussive elements.

use_cases.context: Providing a unique, intimate space for vocals that remains present due to the short pre-delay, but with enhanced dimension and subtle movement from the chorus.
use_cases.eq_rationale: Cleans up vocal plosives and low-end rumble before the reverb, and tames sibilance or harshness that could be amplified by the reverb.
use_cases.eq_prep: High-pass filter vocal track at 150-200 Hz; low-pass filter at 5-7 kHz.
use_cases.send_level: Low to Moderate (-15 dB to -20 dB)
use_cases.send_level_rationale: To subtly place the vocal in the space without making it sound distant or washed out, especially given the very short pre-delay.
use_cases.notes: The very short pre-delay might make the vocal feel 'stuck' to the reverb; careful dry/wet balance is crucial. Can create an interesting lo-fi or indie vocal texture.

use_cases.context: Adding atmosphere and a sense of a specific, contained space to a guitar part. The wide stereo image and chorus enhance lushness and width.
use_cases.eq_rationale: Removes muddiness from the guitar's low end and prevents excessive brightness or fizz from entering the reverb tail.
use_cases.eq_prep: High-pass filter at 120-180 Hz; low-pass filter at 6-8 kHz.
use_cases.send_level_rationale: To immerse the guitar in the space, balancing ambience with the clarity of the dry signal.
use_cases.notes: The 'Basement' character could lend a slightly gritty or raw ambiance, suitable for indie rock or alternative genres.

use_cases.context: Creating a dense, wide, and evolving soundscape. The longer decay, wide stereo, and chorus are highly effective for atmospheric textures and ambient sound design.
use_cases.eq_rationale: Cleans up sub-bass frequencies and tames overly bright or fizzy high frequencies in the reverb tail, which can become fatiguing over time.
use_cases.eq_prep: High-pass filter around 80-100 Hz; low-pass filter around 7-9 kHz.
use_cases.send_level_rationale: To fully envelop the pad or drone in the reverb, maximizing its atmospheric impact.
use_cases.notes: Despite the 'Basement' name, this preset offers a surprisingly lush and evolving character for pads, ideal for creating expansive ambient textures.

audio_engineering.diffusion: Medium-high (60%) and high density, resulting in a smooth and rich reverb tail.

warnings.frequency_buildup: The 'HiShelf Gain' and 'LowShelf Gain' are both positive (0.20), meaning high and low frequencies in the reverb tail will be boosted and decay longer than typical. This unusual setup risks excessive brightness/sizzle in the highs and muddiness/boominess in the lows, especially with a 1.8s decay time, potentially leading to an unbalanced tonal character.
warnings.cpu_usage: The 'Density' setting is at its highest value (3.00), which will result in the smoothest and richest reverb tail but will also significantly increase CPU usage. Additionally, multiple modules (HiFilter, LowShelf, Chorus, Input HighCut) are active.
warnings.low_end_accumulation: The input 'LowCut On' is off, allowing the full low-end spectrum into the reverb. Combined with a positive 'LowShelf Gain' (0.20) which boosts low frequencies in the tail, there's a high risk of significant low-end accumulation and muddiness in the mix, particularly with a 1.8s decay time.
warnings.mono_compatibility: The high 'Stereo Image' (100.00) combined with an active 'Chorus' can introduce phase issues and significantly reduce mono compatibility, potentially causing elements to disappear or sound thin when played back in mono.
warnings.mix_context: A very small 'Room Size' (10.00) combined with a moderate 'Decay Time' (1.8s) and high 'Diffusion' (59.97) may create an unnatural, dense, or metallic-sounding space. The short 'Pre-Delay' (2.00ms) with high 'Diffuse Level' (3.04dB) could blur transients and push the source far back, potentially making it indistinct if used on an insert.

tighter.explanation: To achieve a tighter reverb, we shorten the decay time and reduce the room size for a more confined space. Increasing diffusion smooths out the tail, while enabling the input low-cut prevents low-end mud from entering the reverb. A longer pre-delay enhances clarity by creating more separation between the dry signal and the reverb, and dampening both low and high frequency tails contributes to a more controlled sound.

closer.explanation: To make the sound appear closer, we shorten the pre-delay for more immediacy and increase the early reflections level while decreasing the diffuse tail level. The decay time and room size are slightly reduced, and the input high-cut frequency is raised to allow more high frequencies into the early reflections, enhancing clarity and proximity.

wider.explanation: To widen the stereo image of the reverb, we maximize the stereo image setting, increase the chorus modulation depth for added movement and spread, and increase diffusion for a smoother, potentially wider-sounding tail. Enabling and increasing early reflection spin also contributes to a broader and more expansive spatial effect.

narrower.explanation: To narrow the reverb's stereo image, we reduce the stereo image setting, disable chorus modulation, and slightly decrease diffusion for a more focused tail. Ensuring early reflection spin is off and its amount is set to zero also helps to achieve a more centralized and mono-compatible reverb.

warmer.explanation: To make the reverb warmer, we lower the output high-shelf frequency and significantly dampen the high frequencies in the tail, while boosting the low-frequency tail to make it fuller. The input high-cut frequency is lowered to filter out harsher high-mids before they enter the reverb, reducing the reflectivity of early reflections, and a lower scale contributes to a less metallic sound.

further.explanation: To create a sense of greater distance, we lengthen the pre-delay and significantly reduce the early reflections level while increasing the diffuse tail level. The decay time and room size are increased, and the input high-cut frequency is lowered to filter more highs from the input, making early reflections darker and less present.

looser.explanation: For a looser, more spacious reverb, we increase the decay time and room size for a longer, larger ambient effect. Decreasing diffusion makes the tail more grainy and less dense. A shorter pre-delay makes the reverb more immediate and washes into the dry signal, and disabling the input high-cut allows more high frequencies to contribute to the overall wash. Boosting low and high frequency tail decay makes them linger longer.

brighter.explanation: To achieve a brighter reverb, we raise the output high-shelf frequency and strongly boost high-frequency decay, making highs linger, while dampening the low-frequency tail for clarity. The input high-cut frequency is raised to allow more high frequencies into the reverb, early reflections are increased for prominence, and chorus amount is boosted for added shimmer and liveliness.

description.what: A wide, smooth, and slightly dark reverb preset designed to simulate a larger-than-average room or a smaller hall. It features a moderate pre-delay for source clarity, and a dense, modulated early reflections stage that transitions into a smoothly diffused tail. The high frequencies of both the input and the reverb tail are gently attenuated, contributing to a warmer, less harsh sonic character. It is configured for use as a 100% wet send effect.
description.why: This preset aims to create a cohesive and enveloping large room ambiance, enhancing spatial depth without obscuring the dry signal. The pre-delay maintains separation, while high diffusion and a wide stereo image generate a rich and expansive feel. The subtle high-frequency filtering ensures the reverb remains warm and smooth, preventing harshness, making it suitable for adding 'glue' and spaciousness to a mix without becoming overly bright or distracting.
when: Vocals (for clear, spacious ambience without overpowering)
Pads & Synth Textures (to add width, depth, and smooth sustain)
Acoustic Guitars (to place them in a natural, warm environment)
Snare Drums / Percussion (for a larger-than-life room sound with clear transients)
Orchestral / Cinematic Elements (to create a sense of grandeur and vast space)

audio_engineering.size: Very small (3.00), which can typically be metallic but is likely compensated by high diffusion for a smooth character.
audio_engineering.space_type: Versatile and expansive, offering a 'big' sound due to width and diffusion rather than long decay. More akin to a highly optimized studio room or plate than a natural hall.
audio_engineering.frequency_character: The input signal is high-cut around 4.3kHz (with Q ~4.0) to prevent harsh frequencies from entering the reverb. The reverb tail itself features a subtle high-shelf boost (+0.4dB) at 3.17kHz, adding clarity and brightness to the mid-highs within the filtered input range. Low frequencies in the tail are untouched as the low shelf is off.
audio_engineering.stereo_width: Very wide (100% independent L/R tails), creating a highly expansive stereo image.

use_cases.context: Adding a punchy, wide ambience that enhances the snare's impact without creating a long, muddy tail. The pre-delay maintains attack clarity.
use_cases.eq_rationale: Prevents low-end mud from accumulating in the reverb tail, keeping the snare punchy and defined. The reverb's input high-cut helps further shape the top end.
use_cases.eq_prep: High-pass the dry snare signal (before sending to reverb) around 150-200Hz.
use_cases.send_level_rationale: A noticeable but not overwhelming amount, allowing the dry snare to cut through while benefiting from the wide, diffuse space.
use_cases.notes: The early reflections' subtle modulation ('ER Spin') adds a sense of life, and the high diffusion ensures a smooth texture.

use_cases.context: Providing a clear, present vocal with a sense of space and width without pushing it too far back in the mix or introducing sibilance issues.
use_cases.eq_rationale: Cleans low-end build-up and manages harsh high frequencies *before* they are processed by the reverb, complementing the reverb's internal input high-cut (4.3kHz) for a smoother overall sound.
use_cases.eq_prep: High-pass the dry vocal signal (before sending) at 100-120Hz to remove rumble. Apply a de-esser if needed to address harsh sibilance before it reaches the reverb.
use_cases.send_level_rationale: Subtle depth and width, allowing the vocal to remain upfront and intimate while being enveloped by the space.
use_cases.notes: The 12ms pre-delay is crucial for vocal clarity, separating the dry vocal from the reverb onset. The wide stereo image enhances envelopment.

use_cases.context: Creating a wide, lush, and subtly evolving background texture that provides atmosphere without an excessively long decay that can muddy the mix.
use_cases.eq_rationale: Removes rumble and shapes the pad's frequency range to better integrate with other mix elements, preventing the reverb from emphasizing unwanted frequencies.
use_cases.eq_prep: High-pass the dry pad signal (before sending) around 80-100Hz to remove unnecessary sub-lows. If the pad is overly bright, consider a subtle low-pass at 8-10kHz.
use_cases.send_level_rationale: Allows the pad to sit prominently in the mix, benefiting significantly from the rich, diffuse, and wide atmosphere.
use_cases.notes: High diffusion and a very wide stereo image are ideal for expansive pads. The early reflection modulation ('ER Spin') adds subtle movement and organic feel to the texture.

use_cases.context: Adding a sense of space and dimension to a guitar part without losing its presence or attack clarity. Suitable for solos or wide rhythm parts that need to breathe.
use_cases.eq_rationale: Ensures the reverb focuses on the guitar's core frequencies and high-end sparkle, avoiding a boomy or indistinct low-end from the reverb.
use_cases.eq_prep: High-pass the dry guitar signal (before sending) around 100-150Hz to prevent low-mid muddiness from the reverb.
use_cases.send_level_rationale: A balanced level for spaciousness, allowing the guitar's attack and body to remain clear while being surrounded by the reverb.
use_cases.notes: The 12ms pre-delay helps maintain the guitar's initial punch. The wide stereo image and smooth diffusion create an open, enveloping sound without being overly long.

audio_engineering.diffusion: High (74.67), resulting in a very smooth and dense reverb tail without graininess.

warnings.frequency_buildup: The 'Decay Time' of 1000.22 seconds will lead to massive and uncontrolled frequency buildup across the entire spectrum. This is compounded by 'In LowCut On' being 0.0 (input low cut off), allowing all low frequencies into the reverb, and 'LowShelf On' being 0.0 (low shelf for the tail is off), meaning no attenuation of low frequencies within the reverb tail itself. Additionally, 'HiShelf Gain' is 0.40 (a boost), which will cause high frequencies to accumulate and potentially create harshness or sibilance, especially with such an extreme decay.
warnings.cpu_usage: The 'Decay Time' is set to an exceptionally long 1000.22 seconds. This will demand extreme CPU resources for continuous reflection calculations and sustained audio, making the preset highly inefficient and potentially unfeasible for practical use.
warnings.low_end_accumulation: With 'Decay Time' at 1000.22 seconds, low frequencies will accumulate to an extreme degree. This issue is severely worsened by 'In LowCut On: 0.0', allowing the full low-frequency content of the input source to excite the reverb, and 'LowShelf On: 0.0', which means there is no frequency-dependent decay to thin out the low end of the reverb tail. This will result in overwhelming muddiness, lack of punch, and a completely indistinct low end in the mix.
warnings.mono_compatibility: The 'Stereo Image' is set to 100.00 (very wide), which significantly increases the risk of phase issues or a loss of definition and character when the mix is collapsed to mono.
warnings.mix_context: The 'Decay Time' of 1000.22 seconds (assuming units are seconds as per Ableton Reverb) creates an overwhelming, practically infinite wash that will completely swamp any source signal and obliterate clarity in a mix. The 'Room Size' is extremely small (3.00), which will likely result in an unnatural, metallic, or resonant character, directly contradicting the 'Big Room' preset name. 'Dry/Wet' is set to 100.03% wet, indicating this preset is designed for a send/return track. Using it as an insert effect will completely wash out the dry signal and make the source indistinguishable. The combination of an extremely small 'Room Size' (3.00) and a high 'Scale' (100.00) can exacerbate metallic or overly colored resonance, leading to an undesirable texture for many applications.

tighter.explanation: Reduces the reverb tail length, decreases pre-delay, and reduces low-end buildup to create a more focused and less washed-out sound. Room Size is adjusted slightly up from its extremely small value to reduce metallic ringing and provide a more controlled, albeit still small, space.

closer.explanation: Reduces pre-delay and emphasizes early reflections while decreasing the diffuse tail, making the source sound more immediate and upfront. A shorter decay time and narrower stereo image further contribute to a sense of proximity.

wider.explanation: Maximizes the stereo image to create a broad soundstage. Engaging and increasing the chorus and early reflection spin modulation adds subtle movement and spatial complexity, further enhancing the perceived width of the reverb.

narrower.explanation: Reduces the stereo image to make the reverb more focused towards the center. Disabling chorus and early reflection spin removes modulation that contributes to wider spatial effects, resulting in a tighter, more centralized reverb.

warmer.explanation: Dampens high frequencies in the reverb tail and boosts lower frequencies to create a darker, smoother, and less harsh sound. Input filtering is adjusted to prevent bright signals from exciting the reverb excessively, contributing to an overall warmer tone.

further.explanation: Increases pre-delay and emphasizes the diffuse tail over early reflections, creating a sense of greater distance. A longer decay time and wider stereo image further enhance the perception of the sound source being further away in a larger space.

looser.explanation: Increases the reverb tail length and pre-delay for a more spacious feel. A larger room size and reduced diffusion create a less dense, more open sound, while increased stereo width and subtle chorus add movement and expanse.

brighter.explanation: Emphasizes high frequencies in the reverb tail and reduces low frequencies for a more airy and clear sound. Disabling the input high-cut filter allows more high-frequency content into the reverb, enhancing brightness and sparkle.

description.what: A highly diffused, very long, bright, and wide reverb preset. It features an extensive decay time, emphasizes high frequencies in the tail, includes a significant pre-delay for clarity, and utilizes chorus modulation for added movement and lushness. Early reflections are minimized, focusing almost entirely on the diffuse tail, and it's set to fully wet for send/return applications.
description.why: To immerse a sound in a vast, luminous, and moving spatial environment, pushing it far back in the mix and creating a sense of depth and ethereal beauty. It's ideal for adding a rich, sustained shimmer without making the initial attack muddy, contributing to a dreamy or expansive atmosphere.
when: Vocals (for ethereal, distant, or pad-like effects)
Pads (to create vast, evolving soundscapes)
Ambient synthesizers (for sustained, atmospheric textures)
Guitars (to achieve a shimmery, expansive wash)
Sound design (for creating large, abstract spaces or drones)

audio_engineering.frequency_character: A very bright and open reverb due to minimal high-frequency filtering on input (low-pass at 16kHz). The reverb tail features a slight high-frequency boost (1.0 dB) and a subtle low-mid boost (0.42 dB around 478 Hz). Additionally, a moderate chorus modulation (62% amount, 0.2 Hz rate) is applied to the tail, adding a lush, shimmering quality and enhancing brightness and movement.

use_cases.eq_prep: HPF @ 200 Hz to prevent low-end mud, LPF @ 8 kHz to prevent excessive high-end shimmer from becoming harsh.
use_cases.context: Enhancing a synth pad for a lush, evolving soundscape with a wide, immersive texture.
use_cases.send_level_rationale: Allows the dry pad to remain present while blending in the expansive reverb for atmosphere.
use_cases.notes: The long decay and brightness create an airy, ethereal feel. The wide stereo image and chorus modulation contribute to an immersive texture and subtle movement.

use_cases.eq_prep: HPF @ 180-220 Hz on the send to keep the reverb tail clean and prevent it from muddying the vocal's lower frequencies. Gentle LPF @ 8-10 kHz on the return to soften potential sibilance if the vocal is already bright.
use_cases.context: Placing a lead vocal in a large, emotional space while maintaining clarity and presence.
use_cases.send_level_rationale: Adjust based on the desired prominence of the reverb; higher for more atmospheric, lower for more subtle.
use_cases.notes: The 30ms pre-delay is crucial for vocal clarity, allowing the dry vocal to cut through before the long, bright, and wide tail develops. Consider de-essing the vocal before the reverb send if sibilance is an issue.

use_cases.eq_prep: HPF @ 150 Hz to control low-frequency build-up from a full orchestra, LPF @ 7 kHz on the return if the strings are already very bright and the reverb becomes overpowering in the highs.
use_cases.context: Providing a grand, expansive environment for orchestral sections to enhance scale and epic feel.
use_cases.send_level_rationale: A higher send level is often appropriate for orchestral elements to convey a large, natural acoustic space.
use_cases.notes: The large room size, long decay, and wide stereo image are ideal for creating a spacious and immersive orchestral sound. The brightness adds shimmer to string harmonics.

use_cases.eq_prep: HPF @ 120-150 Hz to clean up the low end of the reverb, preventing muddiness. LPF @ 6-7 kHz on the return if the guitar tone or reverb becomes too piercing or thin.
use_cases.context: Creating large, atmospheric guitar soundscapes, particularly for sustained clean tones or ethereal arpeggios.
use_cases.send_level_rationale: For ambient guitar, the reverb is often a primary textural element, warranting a higher send level.
use_cases.notes: The brightness, long decay, and chorus modulation provide excellent texture for sustained chords and arpeggios, making the guitar feel huge and evolving. The pre-delay can help preserve the clarity of initial guitar attacks.

warnings.frequency_buildup: The long decay (3.3s) coupled with effectively no high-frequency damping (HiFilter Freq at 16kHz with HiShelf Gain 1.00) makes this reverb prone to excessive high-frequency and sibilance buildup, especially on bright or percussive sources. Since input filters are off, any problematic frequencies in the dry signal will directly excite the reverb.
warnings.cpu_usage: With the highest Density setting (3.00), a long decay time (3.3 seconds), large room size, and active modulation (Chorus and ER Spin), this preset will consume significant CPU resources, especially if multiple instances are used.
warnings.low_end_accumulation: While the reverb's internal low-shelf provides a significant cut around 478 Hz, the absence of an input low-cut filter (`In LowCut On: 0.0`) means that all low-frequency content from the source will enter the long 3.3-second decay. This can still contribute to low-end rumble and mud, particularly with bass-heavy or percussive sources, despite the internal low-mid attenuation.
warnings.mono_compatibility: The extremely wide stereo image (100.00) combined with active chorus and early reflection spin modulation means this reverb is highly susceptible to phase issues and significant tonal shifts when collapsed to mono. Test mono compatibility thoroughly.
warnings.mix_context: This reverb's 100% wet, long decay (3.3s), large size, and lack of high-frequency damping can easily wash out a mix with bright, sustained tails. The absence of early reflections (`Reflect Level: -0.00`) means sources will lack immediate spatial definition, sounding dislocated rather than placed in a specific room. Careful application is needed to avoid masking other elements.

tighter.explanation: Reduces decay time and room size, narrows the stereo field, and increases low-end cut in the reverb tail to create a more focused and controlled sound.

closer.explanation: Increases pre-delay to create more separation from the source, and reduces the levels of both early reflections and the diffuse tail, making the source feel more upfront.

wider.explanation: Maximizes the stereo image and increases both chorus and early reflection spin modulation to create a broader and more expansive stereo spread.

narrower.explanation: Reduces the stereo image and decreases both chorus and early reflection spin modulation to create a more focused and centralized reverb.

warmer.explanation: Reduces high frequencies in the reverb tail and increases diffusion to create a smoother, less harsh, and warmer-sounding space.

further.explanation: Decreases pre-delay to blend the source more into the reverb, increases early reflections and diffuse tail levels, and slightly extends decay time to create a greater sense of distance and immersion.

looser.explanation: Extends the decay time and room size, maximizes the stereo image, and adds more modulation to create a more expansive, flowing, and less defined reverb.

brighter.explanation: Boosts high frequencies in the reverb tail and slightly extends its reach to enhance presence and add sparkle to the reverb.

description.what: An extremely large, bright, and highly diffused hall reverb, optimized for send/return tracks. It features a long pre-delay and medium-long decay, combined with maximum room size and diffusion, creating a vast, smooth, and expansive sound. Input filtering is bypassed, ensuring full-spectrum richness, while the low-shelf gently tames low frequencies in the tail for clarity. Subtle modulation is applied to both early reflections and the main tail for added movement and lushness.
description.why: This preset excels at crafting an immense and pristine sense of space due to its maximum room size, long pre-delay (30ms), and 2-second decay. The un-filtered input and the high-shelf at 16kHz maintain brightness, while the attenuated low-shelf (at 173Hz) ensures the vast tail remains clean and free from muddiness. Maximum diffusion and density create an exceptionally smooth, dense tail, further enhanced by subtle ER spin and chorus modulation for a lush, evolving texture. The higher diffuse level over early reflections, combined with a wide stereo image, contributes to an enveloping and distant feel, perfect for adding depth and atmosphere to elements meant to reside in a grand, ethereal environment. Configured for 100% wet, it's ideal for use on a send track to blend this rich ambiance into various sources.
when: Synthesizer pads or atmospheric textures for a vast, evolving soundscape.
Ethereal lead vocals, to place them in a majestic, floating, and clear space.
Ambient guitar parts, adding shimmering depth and width without muddiness.
Sound design elements or drones that require an extremely large, bright, and sustained environmental presence.
Creating a sense of grand, open space in a mix where clarity and brightness are paramount.

audio_engineering.size: Very large, maxed out virtual room size.
audio_engineering.frequency_character: Bright and clear, with prominent high frequencies throughout the decay, due to minimal high-frequency damping. A slight lift in the low-mids (around 173Hz) ensures warmth without muddiness, and the overall character is lively.
audio_engineering.stereo_width: Very wide (120 degrees), creating a truly enveloping stereo image.

use_cases.eq_prep: High-pass filter the vocal's send at 150-200 Hz to prevent low-end mud. Consider a subtle cut around 3-4 kHz on the send if the vocal is already harsh.
use_cases.context: To add presence, shimmer, and a sense of large, ethereal space without losing clarity.
use_cases.send_level_rationale: Moderate-to-high send level for a prominent, present reverb effect that pushes the vocal into a large space, but still allows the dry vocal to lead.
use_cases.notes: The 30 ms pre-delay is crucial for vocal clarity. The bright, wide character, combined with early reflection and chorus modulation, will make the vocal soar with an airy, shimmering quality. The higher diffuse level will push the vocal back slightly, while the overall brightness keeps it lively.
